pros: Not much, maybe one or two friendly staff that will help you when needed.
cons:
In the short time i have worked at Fujitsu, i have found that most but not all staff are not too friendly, most don't even acknowledge or look at you when you greet them. I was not given any training or even an introduction into the process involved to doing my job then they question my numbers are not up to standard, after only 4 weeks? Mind you, they give me the jobs no one else wants to do and then compared my numbers to staff that are doing completely different equipment and who have also been there for a minimum of 3 yrs. I managed to get a "Good work" from a boss higher up, but then get questioned by some "know it all" in a different state (QLD), he asks if I am doing all necessary tests? You don't question someones work methods after they have been told they are doing a good job, you question them when they are doing poorly then you seek to help them! Not to mention my Team leaders sat there silent and didn't even come to my defence.
They also tried to put the blame on me for a part number being entered into the system incorrectly and wanted me to fix it? Hold on, if you go to the base of the problem, there is a less likely chance for it to happen again. I don't mind correcting it but don't point the finger at me and make me fix it every time it happens!

This may be the most toxic environment i have ever worked at.
Advice to Management
Break up the exclusive boys club. Not all foreigners are stupid and will sit back and take your crap.

cons:
NO PAY RISES - NOT EVEN TO KEEP UP WITH INFLATION. All I keep hearing from colleagues and managers is "I haven't had a pay rise for years." Value and respect your staff by awarding an annual pay rise that will at least keep up with inflation - otherwise you are effectively cutting peoples pay and eroding their morale and motivation.

review_title: Broadly OK but too many competing fiefdoms who derail change they don't like
pros:
Decent headline salary and benefit package in line with industry. Healthcare, flexibility to buy / sell holiday, various support for families.
Wide range of services, industries and customers, so always the chance to move and learn.
cons:
Strategy flip-flops and massive reorganisations every couple of years. Little visible leadership commitment to making things work.
Massively inefficient and bureaucratic. Far too many people people shuffling paper, writing processes and adding no value.
Employees first to feel the bite if the forecasts look gloomy - pay freezes, travel bans, recruitment freezes leading to undermanning
Many benefit levels do not change annually, meaning your overall package deteriorates over time
Advice to Management
Pick a strategy, communicate it, stick to it and don't be afraid to remove the game-players who undermine it and want to continue doing things their own way.

review_title: Struggling to keep up with the industry
pros: It is a former group company of one of the leading Japanese manufacturer, Fujitsu., Ltd. The company manufactures and sales a variety of components, allowing to appeal to a wide range of end-equipments and parts. As a company starting off with relay components, it has a strong connection and background to electricity and telecommunication companies in Japan as well as other electronic component companies. Owning their own factory, and designing their products by themselves, the company has a strong control over the products they manufacture, realizing provision of high quality.
cons:
Entering their 20th anniversary, the company culture is starting to become outdated. While the company strives to make flexible moves and tries to change its strategic actions to adapt to the changing market of Japanese electronic component manufacturing, it is struggling to see its effects at the time being. The philosophy of all-the-way-to-the-end by designing in-house, manufacturing internally, and selling by themselves are resulting in high price which further burden them in competition in the market.
Advice to Management
The company is lacking a strong business strategy message to the employees on the future direction of the company. Old culture lingers and a drastic change is needed ASAP in order to strengthen the company.

Stop behaving like children on a playground and show some responsibility.

review_title: Past glory doesn't help in the cloud age anymore
pros:
If you are dealing with Fujitsu Japan, it can be culturally interesting.
Fujitsu is still highly regarded in Japan. Still a great place if you are into certain hardware development aspects.
cons:
Japanese managers have a faint idea about how to do business outside of Japan. They also exhibit exceedingly hierarchical and political thinking. Usually marginal English skills don't help with staff communication - and there's very little of it in the first place. The regional subsidiaries all struggle with the move to the cloud and the shift from old school data centers to hyperscalers - with basically no differentiators. If you are into software development - do yourself a favour and keep your distance.
Advice to Management
Embrace public cloud, embrace SaaS, and showing a little more respect to your employees would be a good move, too. People aren't just numbers.

review_title: Those were the days my friend!
pros:
* The "Fujitsu way" has a great phylosophy and has great vision, but who is following the Fujitsu Way in the management team? Really?!.
*"Human Centric Innovation" made me join Fujitsu
* "Driving a trusted future" made me fight for Fujitsu
* Great opportunities for self learning
* Quality - "REAL" green IT products
* the "REAL" lightest and powerfull noteboks
* powerfull DC and server products which achieved ultimate passmark and test results from several software vendors
* challenging ecosystem
cons:
* lead delivery times
* lack of communication with the management
* pushing for great margins but somehow always failing when it comes to the competition.
* Aprox 25% expensive than any competitors
* no real run rate business because no consumer products but mostly high end-at least outside the Japan
* most of the pretty products are not available outside the Japan.
* Agile phylosophy?...unfortunately everything is slow until it comes to kicking people out, yeah that one is very fast.
* Instead of all cons, Fujitsu is a great company to work and I "still" believe in Fujitsu. On the other hand you have no idea what may happen next week... month... year...things are not stable.
* who is ruling/managing the faith of Fujitsu? There are several faces...inside Japan & outside Japan...anything uotside the Japan is like a big puppet show which you will not enjoy to watch...
* Fujitsu Client Computing Limited ("FCCL") ..perhaps that is the worst thing in the picture.
Advice to Management
Would love to see managers who will follow the Fujitsu Way, otherwise there will be no Fujitsu at all in a few years in the EMEA region...

pros: A way of getting your foot in the door to work for a proper IT desk. We'll, it's suppose to be good for that
cons:
Awful marking system that doesn't make moral or practical sense. You cannot use the toilet more than 30 minutes per month. Everyone can see your agent score, how often you've been using the toilet and you're constantly pressured to meet at least 95 percent on a scoring system that doesn't reflect at all on how professional you are or how we'll you are serving your customer. It's all based on how fast you can get the call finished and how many insidents you manage to close. (closing certainly does not mean solve) usually means you've managed to fob the user off. Progression isn't necessarily given to someone that will be a positive impact to the company. You'll notice that the ones progressing tend to go to the pub with each other and management tend to pick who they think will be a laugh to join their team. Once you aren't an agent you're in the position where you can pass pass responsibility on others and just smoke cigarettes and fart and pretend to look at emails from time to time. Agents are told to buddy up with other agents who are usually very stressed out and do t really need anyone listening to what they're doing and asking questions because they're stressed enough trying to do the job themselves with poor training. The building and everything in it doesn't get cleaned well and looks like it's never been cleaned at all. Agents have brought this to management so many times and usually get a sarcastic response and everyone is told to clean their desk themselves. Management are allowed to isolate every other week and come into office the other but if you're an agent you have to come in every day. The environment in the building I'm working at isnt prepared and made safe for workers during a pandemic. Equipment is broken or of very poor quality and is usually very disgusting. Most of the time there's someone that isn't even able to sit at a seat because the companys hired too many people and doesn't have enough seats or equipment for them. Agents suffer a lot of abuse from customers each day due to people higher up the chain not caring and forgetting to give crucial information and have awful guidance on how to manage situations. You're expected to refer to a knowledge base for any questions the customer might have or to help solve their issue. The information is quite often wrong though or ot updated and when the customer asks why you are left stressed and cannot tell the truth otherwise you could lose your job.

This is my honest experience of the floor I work on and the rest of the building seems a lot nicer and workers are respected more as human being should be.

More money needs to be spend and corners need to stop being cut. There needs to be an over all positive and can do attitude and not just reacting to things going wrong at the last second. pros: The people who work there are mostly very friendly - I got on with the majority of my colleagues. There was also some work from home potential
cons:
The graduate scheme is highly competitive and is constantly talked up in the company - however I had an awful time as did many in my cohort, many of whom left as soon as they could. I was given almost nothing to do, was regularly pitted against my peers, was patronised and treated like a child by many of the older men in SLT. The grad scheme element consisted mostly of 8, fairly useless learning modules that we attended over 2 years. Outside of that there was no support from the grad scheme team who were more interested in recruitment than retainment. Nobody checked in from the wider organisation to see how grads were fairing. Many of the grads who I knew suffered massively with mental health due to the poor support and opportunities provided. We were told by Business Unit leadership that we just needed to be more resilient. 
I personally was given very little work to do or responsibility - despite seeking it out regularly. Then was penalised for such in performance reviews.
Advice to Management
Actually listen to your graduates, check in on them. Focus some of the attention on actually supporting the cohort, rather than just recruiting.

review_title: Seems like a great company to work for so far, great atmosphere and great opportunities
pros: Having worked here for only 6 or 7 months, I've been working remotely (Covid) and have not actually met my colleagues in person yet. However I have still been accepted into the team and feel part of them. My opinions are valued and my voice is heard within my Project team. This also seems to be the case outside of the team though I haven't had much experience with this as of yet. My manager is very good at recommending training and opportunities. He is very good at breaking down the information disseminated from the higher ups which is good considering that it is a very large company. They are very flexible in working hours however it seems as though they will not be continuing significant WFH arrangements after covid. They on the whole do seem to value their workforce and want to look after it which is more than can be said for most SIs. There is a lot of talk around diversity and inclusion in the company which is great.
cons:
While my manager is good at recommending training, I rarely seem to get any time to do it! The job is fast paced and there is little room for rest, let alone doing some training in the day. Their IT infrastructure is not the most up to date, many seem to be being given older laptops when the join, though I think I was a lucky one and got a new laptop. They could implement better in-company communication systems as Skype really does suck at the moment. (Why skype can't just keep a conversation string going day-to-day is beyond me!)
Advice to Management
Allow (especially at the moment with the pandemic) and encourage employees to take some time during the working week to do training. I understand that this can be done outside of work hours and many are happy doing that. I already end up working longer hours than I should for the project I am on and as such I end up having to do any training outside of those hours which means I rarely get a lot of meaningful training done!

pros: There's potential there, but it constantly falls flat.
cons:
Work and promotions are given by favour, not by ability, skill, or past experiences. If you're loud, pushy, and steal others' work, you'll be noticed. If you're a white guy, you'll always be given a seat at the table (even if others "outrank" them). You'll be welcomed by superiors to join their ranks regardless of your actual output. If you're a woman or a person of color, you'll have to work twice as hard to get noticed half as much. There are managers there that will openly tell you they care about their personal reputation first, far past their own team. I have heard managers (that were being recorded) yell and scream to get their way when what they wanted was going to hurt their customers (and did!). If you try to put the customer first, they will silence you, dismiss you, and talk over you to get their way. 

They encourage this behavior by continually rewarding these blokes and giving them more responsibility. Sales is set up against each other so departments are fighting over the same work without the customer's best interest in mind. The work silos prevent new work from ever coming in and wastes so much effort. A lot of talent working there now is just waiting to be offered the right opportunity to leave but COVID messed everything up. Still looking.
Advice to Management
It's great to talk about diversity, but there's so many departments that have absolutely none. It should be natural, not a token seat at the table to pretend to be heard (but at this point, even a token seat would be a step up). We get asked for our thoughts and the mangement teams run away with them. They'll get the bonus while you get the crumbs and a stalled career. Go team.

pros: None to be completely honest.
cons:
They refuse to compensate appropriately.
Advice to Management
Weak management with no spine to stand up for employees and the NZ branch is technically been given over to Fujitsu Australia, Fuj NZ makes a profit, but Fuj Aus does not, but they siphon the funds from Fuj NZ and pay Fuj Aus staff handsomely but do not do any better, this company disregards those who are actually making money for them.

There are some good mid level staff members and it is interesting work that exposes you to different environments of the clients and alternate approaches to a single problem. But this is not due to some inherent virtue of the company.

The $61,000 compensation for a System Engineer is nonsense for a full time employee, only contractors who do half the work and have a quarter of the knowledge get that. There has been no pay rise for the past 2 years, though Fujitsu made a profit for the 2019 FY they still are not giving out any pay rises, so this is a on going issue.

There is also rampant cronyism and gate-keeping of knowledge by many of the staff as they seem to value their own jobs over any semblance of team work.

One of the worst places for getting a good paying job.

pros:
Job stability
Health insurance plan
Optional gym pass
cons:
Unprofessional attitudes by supporting functions and some management staff
Endemic shortage of staff due to bad management policies and practices
Lack of interest in employee retention or development
Lack of interest in educating users from customer companies
Career progression hampered by office politics and favoritism
Discrimination and xenophobia by customers and by people inside the company
Toxic workplace environment
Low salaries
Atrocious HR department
Inappropriate conduct protected and rewarded
Advice to Management
Resign.

When you take in driven, motivated people who are interested in doing good work and place them in an environment where they have to deal with colleagues and supervisors gossiping about their personal life and badmouthing them behind their backs, morale is sure to suffer. 

Add to that the fact that career progression seems to often be held back by office politics and that higher management would rather often hire someone from outside than give an active employee the opportunity to climb up and you have a recipe for disaster, especially considering that other companies offer considerably higher salaries for the same kind of work. People might be willing to work an entry level job for comparatively less as long as they feel there is the possibility of progression, but when they keep getting shut down by biased parties despite delivering consistently good performance, then they will be sure to start looking for other alternatives. 

It does not help that people are too often selected for promotion based not on competence but on who they are friends with, or simply on nationality. Career progression is nearly impossible for foreigners in many departments. More competent candidates are consistently harmed either by not being given the dates of the assessments with enough time in advance to prepare for them, or having those assessments scheduled right after strenuous work, with no time to rest beforehand.

Other than the fact that a considerable amount of supporting and management staff enjoy gossip and interfering other people's personal life, there are also inappropriate and downright criminal behaviors taking place at some departments, such as xenophobic attitudes (both from customers and from Fujitsu staff), inappropriate conversations being held in the workplace in front of everyone and sexual harassment, all of which have been reported to management and HR and are consistently ignored. 
Supervisors and managers in some departments are also known for ignoring and mistreating foreigners - from consistently trying to deny them opportunities for advancement to giving them the worst shifts or trying to force them to constantly change scheduling arrangements for the benefit of the local favorites, or even screaming loudly at them in the middle of the workplace and using demeaning language. 

Never before in my life have I seen people behaving this way in the workplace, especially at a multinational company. There are also cases where supervisors try to force first line agents to work seven days in a row or ignore the mandatory rest times between shifts as per Polish labor law. Other times, employees who refuse this inappropriate treatment are singled out for retaliation, mobbing, harassment and false disciplinary claims in an attempt to intimidate them. The Fujitsu Way is Omerta.

It is nearly impossible for bad employees to get fired, and they are often promoted as a way of getting rid of them. Competent and committed employees are frequently ignored. Several projects have people in positions of responsibility who want to do the bare minimum and treat people actually interested in working with disdain and hostility. As long as the service level agreements are met and the customers are happy, no action is taken.

Equipment is frequently shoddy, badly maintained and there is an absolute lack of interest by many supervisors in providing tools and access rights that are required for basic daily tasks. It can take months for simple repairs to be performed since the onsite technicians are chronically understaffed and don't care at all. Some internal resolver groups are known for ignoring high priority service disruptions for days on end.

In the same vein, the HR department is frankly dishonest and incompetent, often taking an eternity to update employee data, misplacing important documents or not filing them at all, especially when dealing with visas and recruitment initiatives where an existing employee is supposedly eligible for a bonus by introducing a new potential recruit. Anyone reporting instances of inappropriate behavior to HR also only end up making themselves a target for further retaliation or being completely ignored.

All of these issues were previously reported and no action was taken. One other employee who was the victim of sexual harassment was not only ignored for months but also basically told something along the lines of "we spoke to the person and it only happened once, so what's the problem?" This is patently false as the perpetrator has done this to several people. Not only has this criminal kept their job but they were actually rewarded with a promotion.

review_title: Overall Good Company to work for
cons:
ltant in Bracknell, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Worked at Fujitsu for 13 years starting first at Fujitsu Siemens and then merged into Fujitsu. Was difficult at times to find training opportunities whilst in first role I had at Fujitsu. 

Most recent role at Fujitsu was able to get some good training opportunities, would like to have done more was probably just my laziness!
Cons
I was made redundant from my role at Fujitsu which I appreciate companies need to do sometimes but I was not happy with the way they handled it which was disappointing considering this is a large company who has done this a few times you'd think they'd learn.

We had a scoring process which was delayed but my exit date was not put back as a result of this sort I had quite short notice from being told I was selected to when I left. Also the company were saying that they were helping to find redeployment opportunities for you which they weren't really, they were simply advertising roles to us and providing other resources to help with this.

They did however, provide training for help with looking for work in the future such as CV workshops, Linkedin workshops and Interview workshops.

Also whilst in my previous role had been trying to get my job grade increased but always told by managers that they're pursuing HR to get it done and anything else which required HR involvement never got done. Seemed like HR ran the company instead of senior management.
Advice to Management
Remove the annoying HR red tape.

review_title: Where to begin, Insane management who don’t have a clue what is happening to there business
pros: Usually paid at least one a month
cons:
No work/life balance: not sure why other people say it has a good work life balance. My experience is that they expect you to do on-call once a month, do patching and application releases overnight or on weekends (often with only minimal notice) as well as be able to answer the phone when not on-call, just in case. All the while, expecting you to study for exams to get certifications which you will never use because they are so far behind.
Low pay: Most of the base pay is below industry standards, most pay rises were about 1% per year, the last 2 years there were no pay rises, and Management justified it because they lost too many contracts. So the workers end up suffering because the management can't keep the current clients.. 
Annual Leave: In the past few years, because they are losing money, they started to force people to take annual leave, First it was you have to take 20 days per financial year, then it was that you can't have a balance over 8 at the end of the financial year, the next year, it was down to a balance of 7.
This cause you to take annual leave mostly in the final month of the financial year (March cause it is a Japanese company) which is also quiet a busy time, which means staff are missing at important time.
Redundancies: Over the past 4 years, they have been making staff redundancy at regular intervals. Firstly it was one a year (usually around June/July) but since then, they have been making people redundancy in small lots (1-2 a week) this mean moral is rock bottom, and most staff don't know what is happening when they come to work on a Monday.
Advice to Management
Sack the Leaders of the Melbourne operation. Staff have no confidence in there management..

review_title: Good starting salary but bad raises and no growth opportunities
cons:
ltant in Vancouver, BC
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
-Flexible(ish) work environment
-Good starting salary
Cons
- No career growth opportunities
- Once they lock you in at a given starting salary, your raises will be slim to none. I'm pretty sure that if you account for inflation, I (as well as several friends/teammates) was making less when I left than when I started despite being there for 3+years
Advice to Management
I think it's fairly obvious to everyone working there that you make a lot of "promises" (most of them implied, nothing in writing of course) to get talented people to come on board but once they are there, the company will always find a way to not own up to them. 

Some examples:

-Strong work from home policy emphasized when I got hired but it was very rarely approved unless there were extenuating circumstances. The only logic I ever got was that it might look bad if the client came on-site and people were working from home...then why mention it in the first place?

-Emphasized the bonus program when I first got hired...I can't remember the last time anyone actually got a bonus though. They would always address this by saying certain metrics weren't met in other regions and since all regions are tied together, our region wouldn't get the bonus. Very frustrating considering you as an individual or team could exceed your targets for the year and not get recognized for it...

pros:
Good interesting work to be done, when assigned/ allowed. 
Minimal supervision of work, trusted to get on with it.
cons:
Psychotic bad tempered managers - this is no exaggeration. I was screamed at more than once for minor transgressions, such as being 5 mins late, while others in the team got away with much more. This is blatant victimisation.

Also experienced direct side-lining. Forced to do nothing for months while team I was supposed to be a part of were extremely busy.

Cronyism rife - frequently saw other less experienced colleagues promoted to more senior tech. positions/ management, because they were in favour. 

Over reliance on contractors, to the detriment of permanent staff. Contractors were frequently hired to do work that others, with little to do could do with ease/ minimal handover or training. This appeared to be cronyism again.

Lack of promotional/ developmental opportunities for those not part of the in-crowd. 


Wage rises small and infrequent. 

Staff performance appraisals seem to be paper ticking exercises. Management did not use these to seriously develop/ progress staff, in my experience. The get-out clause for them seems to be "your development is your responsibility". However if blocked from training or promotion to more interesting teams, while seeing colleagues routinely moved between teams to fill new positions, or promoted to new positions, which were never advertised, this feels extremely unfair.
Advice to Management
Respect/ treat your staff better. We are not just "resources", as was often said.

Do not turn a blind eye to bullying. 

Talk to sidelined/ isolated staff. Actively work to change the situation for the better.

Treat others are you would like to be treated yourselves.

pros:
Working from home option.
Salary sacrifice options so beneficial taxwise.
Large enough to move around and try new roles.
cons:
Where to start...
Pay is diabolical, especially so being a woman as I'm paid less than my male peers, but nobody wants to acknowledge that, obviously.
Been through the redundancy cull multiple times in my career with Fujitsu, so it's a common occurrence leaving staff wondering where the axe will fall next. Re-orgs are mainly to blame for said culls, and Fujitsu does love a re-org. Also the redundancy process is an absolute farce and badly managed every time.
No transparency (or logic) re salaries for each grade so if applying for a new internal position you have no idea what the pay range is, and finding out is a challenge to say the least.
Female ratio low (20% at last count I believe).
Old boys network is rife in terms of redundancies (they avoid it) and progression (they make it).
Very old fashioned outlook ie lacks agility. Any new ideas are slow to be realised and by the time they are it's too late as we're over the curve.
Pay rises virtually non-existent and best way to get one is to leave and come back.
Japan is now wanting to regionalise again, yet globalisation is key to success. But hey, it must be time for yet ANOTHER re-org so why not!?!
Advice to Management
Treat your females more fairly as, believe it or not, we're just as talented as the men so deserve equal pay. 
As we go through yet another cull, push aside old boy network loyalties and keep the RIGHT people instead of the senior team's mates.
Take innovation and run with it....don't stifle the good ideas from your people and bury it in bureaucracy....instead get the Labs working on it, getting ideas to market ASAP.
Now is the time to look forward, not backward, if you want Fujitsu to survive.

pros: Fujitsu FCPA was overall a great company to work for. They have a set number of dollars they can give you for a base salary but have other things to offer like car allowance. They want to make sure you feel well compensated for your role. They also provide a stipend for gym/club memberships which adds to your overall well being and helps decrease stress. I worked remote which is always a nice setup. I traveled extensively for my role, which came at no surprise since they were very transparent during the interview process.
cons:
Being a remote employee I felt it was difficult to show my worth when I was not on a team that directly generated revenue or had a way to track ROI of our efforts. It was difficult to build internal relationship as we were very siloed. There also was no upward mobility due to the small size of the BU I worked in. Although if you may be interested in a career change they do encourage lateral changes so starting out in one role may lead you to a whole different role. Working at Fujitsu was a great opportunity to sharpen my people and account management skills as well as indirectly work in many different industries. If I could do it all again I would have taken more initiative to get on a call with my different colleagues, including my boss, one on one at least once a week to see how we can work together to advance internal initiatives. I would have also put more effort into changing their overall strategy for our team as It very clearly was not working.
Advice to Management
The strategy of convincing potential partners to commit most of, if not all of, the resources to complete a project initiated by Fujitsu is going to slow the growth of the partner network rendering the partner network strategy ineffective. Owning the cost and resources for a project would allow you to onramp more partners. Then you can work with the partner marketing team to go to market transfering residual marketing costs to the new partner.

pros: Genuinely don't think any exist any more. I had to give the Company 1 star overall rating because it wouldn't let me submit it otherwise
cons:
I felt there was strong evidence of repeated breaches of Fujitsu's Bullying Harrassment & Victimisation guidelines, specifically setting impossible objectives, deliberate wrong apportionment of blame, blocking training without business justification & insistence their way was the right way. This culminated when I had to send a 6am text to my manager from the hospital after a close family member was rushed in during the night for life-saving brain surgery and I returned to work to be placed on a Performance Improvement Plan, despite not taking any time off sick during the 8 years I worked there.

I queried with Manager 1 why you would use a family member's brain surgery for this and was told that wasn't what happened because "the PIP doesn't say anything brain surgery. It says family emergency and it was a family emergency".
I entered it in the feedback form for Manager 2's appraisal with Manager 3, but got no response from either of them
I queried it with Manager 4 who told me he couldn't give an answer because he was 52
I entered the comments in the Employee Opinion Survey but got no response from anybody
I queried with Manager 5 (who wasn't a manager at the time of the incident) and was told "That was before I was the manager. I don't know what happened and I don't want to know. I don't care"
Finally after I had a leaving date I contacted Manager 3 again asking for a 1-2-1 to try and get an explanation for what happened which she initially agreed to but, upon learning what I wanted to discuss, she cancelled the meeting stating no good would come of it
Advice to Management
I would have thought you would want to keep your best members of staff and prior to any of this happening I had exceeded all of my objectives for 4 consecutive years so I don't understand why you think this behaviour is beneficial to the business.
If things have reached a point where an employee feels the need to report bullying, they should at least be entitled to have a manager ask to see the evidence and then later an explanation of "Yes, that's what happened. Here's why..." or "No, that's not what happened. Here's what happened..." For all I know, my experiences may not be classed as bullying, but for 6 different managers to refuse to even investigate it is unacceptable.

review_title: Wonderful people but poor culture....to unstable
pros: Fujitsu has lots of pros in regards to technology and future possibilities! I’ve worked full-time for 5 years. Wonderful co-workers and mid level management. Great work life balance. The first 3 years many of us developed fantastic careers and thrived. The culture was about developing and sustaining good talent. Managers mentored and engaged their employees.
cons:
The past 2 years significant changes and people passing the buck on failures has created major issues within the company. Loss of business being the main issue. Employees who once thrived either lost their jobs or terrified they are next. Cutting staff and good people for management failures is not good culture. Zero communication. And the feeling you are no longer valued after years of dedication. This isn’t dead weight. These are people working multiple jobs to help keep the train on the tracks. Now too many people are stretched way too thin.
Advice to Management
Stop making knee jerk reactions. Plan more. Engage with the people who help build a positive work environment, who are dedicated and want to see Fujitsu succeed. Hold Sales Teams accountable. Follow through on current initiatives! DO NOT KEEP CUTTING BUDGETS TO NOTHING. And STOP laying off employees that do the necessary work to enable success. Get rid of under performers. I 100% believe that if they can get past this rebuilding phase and stay focus on their initiatives, Fujitsu will go on a huge upswing. But they must stay focused and remember the little guys and show appreciation! The everyday employees are super dedicated and are willing to tackle any challenge. Truly the employees make this company a great place to work! Now Upper Management needs to understand this!

pros:
Very few decent, talented and enjoyable colleagues. A pleasure to work with them.

No other pros.
cons:
Working with outdated systems and tools in an IT/Tech company.... And on top of that, lackluster training and information provided by supervisors.

No real incentive to stay.

Recruit people according to the job's requirements. Do not recruit qualified and/or talented people to do tedious irrelevant tasks. Explain new recruits the full scope of their banal job so they understand from the start what to expect.

review_title: Good to get experience then get out
pros: Potential for good salary; good chance for easy promotion if you love playing corporate politics; relatively easy to get promoted into position without relevant skills or experience. Good marketing and strong graduate hiring program. Management have good understanding of current technology trends.
cons:
Micro managing Australian CEO with a history of poor results but still allowed to run company into the ground after many years; Japanese senior management allow the rot to continue. Huge influx of inexperienced graduates lack any decent mentorship within the company, it is like “blind leading the blind”; experienced people leaving in droves, increases pressure on those left behind. Management keen to respond to glass door online reviews but missing in action when providing feedback internally. Offshoring more and more roles, but most are very low quality offshore teams, continually creating issues that need locals to fix up. Low morale. Depressing work place. Actual delivery capabilities don’t match all the marketing hype. Unable to transform understanding of technology trends into real world applications and successful implementations that go beyond POCs. Does not practice what it preaches - internal IT environment not remotely close to solutions recommended for customers.
Advice to Management
Talk to your staff

Advice to Management
Invest, don't cut your way out of decline. Put Americans on the Board if you want to be global. Force HQ employees to only work in English. Refresh buildings and culture to attract talented young graduates--and then challenge them and promote them rapidly.

review_title: The worst move I ever made
pros:
Apparently UK&I has a reputation as a good place to wind down your career.
It is technically undemanding (if you like that) you will not need update skills or knowledge
cons:
I moved to UK&I from a senior management role in a leading IT company. It is not what I was promised.

One of the big challenges in Fujitsu is the quality of management and leadership. A lot of managers have been over promoted and lack the necessary business skills and qualifications to be effective. It is extremely difficult to find an MBA in UK&I. When new talent is brought in it is often side lined by VP’s who ether don’t know how to use it or feel threatened by it. 

Staff productivity and motivation is low and a lot of staff have been in the same role in Fujitsu for 20-30 years and have out of date skills and market understanding. This also blocks new talent coming in to the business and development and promotion of talent in the business.

The culture is very process heavy to compensate for the low skill base and ineffective management. Internal business services are just not fit for purpose. 

IT and IT management terrible. Internal IT forgets who the customer is and fails to understand the needs of the business effectively.

I have found HR to lack integrity and be untrustworthy. Get everything writing and signed by HR. Keep your own copy or it will be missing form your file when needed (no emails).
Advice to Management
To survive Fujitsu UK&I needs to become a lot faster and more agile. You needs to desperately bring in new talent that can change the way you work. When you do bring talent you need to make them senior enough to actually do some goo. Show more integrity and treat staff with respect (not like fools).

review_title: Fujitsu Laboratories of America FLA Research Researchers
pros: - There are some great people in the lab
cons:
- The current CEO laid off ~25% of the researchers in the lab in November 2017. Several people were in the middle of visa processing and their stay in the United States was put in jeopardy. Several people had been with the company for less than a year. There was no budget reason for the lay off, and an explanation/justification was not provided (to those laid off or to the remaining employees). If you are looking for stable employment, this is not the place for you. 

- New CEO and SVP are sent from Japan every 3-4 years. Some of them are great, and some of them are not. There is no continuity of leadership or research strategy. How this affects researchers, for example, is that when a new CEO comes in, he may decide that what a particular researcher has been doing over the *past* several years is not valuable and therefore the researcher should not be promoted (even though the researcher may have had no say in what they were working on). 

- There are also some very bad managers within the labs . Despite reports to HR and executive management, and many people leaving these managers' groups (and even interrupting their green card application processing to do so), they are not only tolerated but promoted. Managers really do have all the power here.

- Researchers want to come to the labs to do research but only some groups do research, while others heavily focus on standards, and still others focus almost exclusively on implementing prototypes. Make sure you know what you are getting into.

- A lot of interesting work cannot be conducted in the labs in the US but is instead reserved for the labs in Japan. Unlike researchers in Japan, local researchers here have to constantly apply for funding and justify and re-justify their approach and their work. This makes us feel like second-class citizens.

- Gender diversity within the labs is dismal. There is currently only 1 woman researcher in Sunnyvale. There are no attempts to recruit, retain or mentor women. In fact, 4 (out of 5) were laid off in November! There are no women in management on the research side and there have not been any over the past 10 years at least, maybe more.
Advice to Management
- Fujitsu needs to stop treating local researchers as second-class citizens, show them that their contributions are valued and give them better opportunities to transfer their work to products in Japan. 
- Bad managers should be weeded out. They destroy employee morale and drive out some of the most talented employees.
- The labs need local executive leadership that is in tune with US and Silicon Valley corporate practices and is invested in the long-term success of the lab.

review_title: Good Stepping Stone / Bad Staying Place
pros: I was fortunate to have a good manager out of Richardson who was mindful of my workload and the scope of my projects, which made it easy to balance my work and home time.
cons:
Not all managers care about work/life balance. Communication between divisions and department levels is minimal and causes many issues when trying to implement new processes or improvements. Transferring within the company is almost never done, this is due to preconceived notions about people from certain divisions and poor management communication.
Advice to Management
Communication is key, there is too much bureaucracy/red-tape that is holding Fujitsu America back. There are a lot of ideas with little follow through, as most people are using Fujitsu as a stepping stone to a better place - another company on the resume - rather than looking to stay with Fujitsu because of the lack of growth and poor communication. Your current management in place seems like they are more "followers" rather than "Leaders", and Fujitsu needs more leadership to ensure they get a seat at the table.

review_title: Worst Company i have ever worked with
pros: I worked with Fujitsu as a Cluster Finance director started last year and left the company in less than a year, there is no Pros Fujitsu has as a business which makes it remarkable or extinctive work place and comparable to the sum of horrible things I have seen
cons:
i will write honestly from what i saw as i had to leave the company last summer after working for almost a year with them as Finance Director.
as they say Finance is the mirror of every Business.
 
Fujitsu EMEIA has weak management and suffers from so many internal and systems issues, you cant find words to describe the turbulence, infighting, changes in decisions, so many systems and power positions with different views, management has no clear vision and no experience at all, they care about how to get their salaries end of the month and fight at year end for their bonuses after firing their teams members, each country acts differently and independently.

I was shocked when I attended the first region controlling meeting at UK office Baker St.22 with how much Fujitsu lags behind new business models and modern systems and knowledge, the problem is that in merger between Fujitsu Technology Solutions-Germany and Fujitsu Services -UK in one company the leadership assigned internally in UK has no knowledge of Products business which is totally different , ( there is famous organizational rule says "beneath surface changes old power structure remains and the old structure is added to the old one like a house with additions, things get confusing and no one knows what to do". 
company management has no clue of how to run a multiregional activities and showed no interest in remote regions in general , in Middle east Turkey and India management is in deep corruption and misconduct , overall you feel managers at Fujitsu either run business and manage teams fire and hire as if its their own company ? 
legal problems I have seen everywhere and issues of misconduct is huge at Fujitsu, really in deep trouble, paying bribes to third party through their resources vendors to win deals and they never get these projects delivered and late dues and legal issues start cumulating. 
So many people are on the bench, EMEIA puts hidden headcounts in remote regions to exclude them from transformation plan in Europe, eventually who loses his job in Fujitsu are those real professional and hard working people I met within the company.
So many ERP systems in Fujitsu they spent 3+ years to decide which ERP they want to go with eventually they will fail to implement any in current chaos.

Internal audit In Germany is weak, they even visited my Cluster before I joined the company and put so many trivial points without noticing that some companies in the cluster has no ERP and issuing sales invoices manually ??.
they didn't notice that some companies are joint ventures to facilitate local businesses in illegal way ?

When I tried to implement new system the management objected and constrained the whole project.
they refused to assign new procurement managers because they are paying high resources costs to third party vendors while Fujitsu resources are enjoying their time at home ? saying we don't have budget despite they hired enormous headcounts in HR and service delivery without having projects ?

in terms of work life balance its the most horrible place i have ever seen, they don't respect their employees time and days off, due to pattern of chaos everything is Urgent, the recent survey done internally showed revealed shocking outcome of employees engagement and enablement, some senior managers had been hit by chairs.
 
I always wondered why good productive and valuable people left this company in the past until I discovered all these issues after 6 months from joining .
 "i don't recommend Fujitsu as my personal advice before anyone gets himself embroiled with this bad handicapped business, please think of another opportunity - don't ever believe this is an international business, its laterally a Grocery run by Bunch ......... "not everything shines is Gold"
Advice to Management
My Advice goes to Fujitsu JAPAN who are still sleeping and Oblivion.... if you want to make a good company transformation to bring Fujitsu Global to competitive position like old ICL and old Fujitsu-Siemens , fire EMEIA top management Fire all your management everywhere, bring new blood, new professional leaders, real entrepreneurs , so many are their in other ICT global players.

pros: If you are lucky and get to work on a big deal you can do well. You need to be in the Senior Clique generally to do well. Comp and benefits are good but you need to negotiate well when you join as pay rises have been poor for the last few years.
cons:
Targets seem to be a moveable feast from year to year with little link to individual opportunity/sector. You only get paid if above 50% of threshold which creates a bizarre effect in the second half of the year when people either realize they won't get there and either sandbag deals for the following year, pass them over to someone else who will hit threshold and hope they can agree a brown paper bag deal or accept that they won't get paid a bonus and start looking for a new job either internally or externally. Huge sales turnover at the moment so suffering from corporate memory failure. Last 2 years 'Transformation' has been hugely disruptive and many senior leadership roles are vacant (UK MD) or have interim post holders not empowered to take the tough decisions. All exacerbated by very cautious/conservative Japanese Parent company.
Advice to Management
Make your mind up about how you want to organise your sales teams. Set some realistic targets and other KPI's at the beginning of the year not 1/3rd of the way through.
Get some serious Sales Directors who understand their industry sectors, are credible in front of customers, inspire their teams and turn up for work more than 3 days a week. Stop hiring people with IT infrastructure backgrounds - you have enough of them already. The new world is about solving business issues. Reinvigorate the Sales culture, there is no buzz or passion at the moment, it all feels pretty stale.

review_title: Satisfying and frustrating in equal measure
pros: I love this company because of its people. In a 39 year career, my 4 years at Fujitsu have been some of my most rewarding. Not for the salary and benefits, frankly I could (and have) earned much more elsewhere. I love it because I feels that they genuinely value their employees and want you to succeed. Opportunities are there to make an active contribution if you wish and ‘disruptors’ are welcomed
cons:
In an increasingly digitised marketplace Fujitsu are struggling to hold their place in the market and are having a bit of a mid life crisis. We must evolve or risk going the way of Nokia etc.... we still have outdated practices and processes that conflict with the new paradigm and that causes disconnects and discomfort especially where there are multiple change initiatives going on across the EMEIA region. Finding clear guidance on the overcomplex go to market offerings is bewilderingly mind bogglingly frustratingly painfully difficult
Advice to Management
Simplify the go to market services. Do not impose bureaucratic processes on your employees that stifle creativity and crush good will. Trust us and you (and the shareholders) will be rewarded 10 fold

review_title: Supportive organisation who develop people well - weak go-to-market execution
pros:

- Portfolio based regional P&L structure gives autonomy to regions
- Strong client base
- Great organisation to develop your career and get cross-sector experience
cons:

- Japan HQ do not understand western markets and complicate working environment
- Huge focus on reorganisation to solve the companies problems
- Over-complicated company operating model
- Weak on offshore and limited IP, which will ultimately lead to revenue decline unless FJ embraces a major global aquisition
Advice to Management
- Sell the products group
- Aquire an established $1b+ industry focussed s/w entity to bring back relevence
- Invest and promote your technical talent, who are your No. 1 asset rather than investing in your operational managers, who lack content

Regional leadership trying to translate global strategy; some dreadful outdated internal IT portals from the ICL era; some dreadful new internal IT that is a UX nightmare. Work harder to find and nurture the talented. Be bold in pushing globalization but never compromise on quality to try to trim costs. Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
An excellent company to work for and I love the location, since the office is attached to a shopping centre and close to a park. They offered me to stay at a hotel for a week until I moved into a Fujitsu owned house (rent costs are above local average however). The company also offers a type of debit card that can be used in grocery shops and restaurants (as a form of lunch allowance) and they offer medical insurance.

The job itself is typically as you'd expect. You get calls from clients and you have to help them to fix their issues. There's a laid back, yet professional atmostphere around the office and most managers are very nice.
Cons
The biggest downside is that the job is not very challenging even though it is a challenge to get your work done in time, since the FJ ticketing system lags very often.
Advice to Management
Since the salary is quite low, people keep looking for other jobs and this really hurts your employees motivation to do a good job. I'd say, motivate them to stay by giving them a higher salary. That way, you also save costs on having to hire and train new people all the time. Other than that, I loved my time in Portugal and at Fujitsu.

Toxic back-stabbing unsupportive culture - in several capital cities.

review_title: Concerned about the long term viability of the business
pros:
There are many good, smart and collaborative people. You don't always have to spend time on Machiavellian plans to get people to help you.

Great apprentice programme, some of the 18/19 years olds are given the opportunity to make an impact and get valuable experience. 

There are some good products/solutions, if only the GTM was better executed. The whole K5 cloud proposition could be promising given open source roots but has limited traction outside Japan to date. There is a question over whether FJ can/will invest enough to truly compete with Google/Microsoft/Amazon who have been growing in this space very strongly. Many other large SI's have capitulated already.

The annual Fujitsu Forum in Munich is a very well organised event and a great showcase for the breadth of solutions on offer.

Good company benefits and expenses policy (decent car scheme - an L grade can get you a £45k Mercedes, 10% pension contribution (if you pay 10%) and a pot of flexible benefits that can be bought/sold if required), will pay for a good quality hotel if you need to stay away. 

The London office is in a vibrant location (close to tube, cafe's, restaurants etc) but seating can be at a premium if you're not early and usual issues around getting meeting rooms.

There is respect for personal time and flexible working isn't a problem, at my level anyway.

Internal cafes are at subsidised prices. Less than £1 for a coffee and quality is ok. Vending machines serve free drinks (if you can put up with the quality/plastic cups).

There is limited BYOD (no laptops) but you can connect your phone/tablet to corporate Exchange so you don't have to use the awful Windows Phone you get given. It works a lot better on iOS (native) than Android (you have to download and use a clunky 3rd party productivity app).

You can request a corporate credit card to cover expenses. The expenses and travel booking system has been replaced & improved recently. Any personal expenses get paid pretty quickly and if you take a company car you get a fuel card (but have to re-imburse private mileage).

Japanese colleagues are wonderful hosts, if you are lucky enough to travel to Japan. 

There is investment available to build new solutions but it has a short term ROI expectation. FJ is in need of better technical visionary leadership to build the right things, not just "anything and hope".

Genuinely promotes diversity and community responsibility. Most of my colleagues are kind and considerate.
cons:
It has realised a little too late the emerging trends and is scrabbling around to be relevant in the market. 

Still overly reliant upon a number of large accounts and (in the UK) the defence business to prop up the rest of the business. EMEA integration still a "work in progress" with much confusion around the operating model. 

Not at all agile, too much governance and process, even for small deals. Cultural reluctance to take risk. 

There is a big disconnect between what (and how things) happen in Japan and elsewhere in the world. And with that, little connection between what EMEA is doing and what North America is doing, despite common leadership. The Japanese skill of incremental innovation isn't wearing well in the new disruptive world.

It may right itself but many good people have been let go whilst there is still a lot of dead wood, many checking on whether people are doing their jobs properly. It's not uncommon to get on weekly operational calls and have 20 senior leaders present, half of who don't contribute. This is (or used to be!) the Public Sector mentality of looking busy but not actually being productive. Perhaps a hang up from the "old days" that needs to be sorted out.

Not a lot of organised social events/clubs (but colleagues are up for post-work socialising).

Bonus has been almost none existent (unlike promise during interview). Depending on the scheme you have very little personal ability to affect what you get.
Advice to Management
All the talk/marketing around agile/digital/innovation needs to be put into practice. Not enough time has been given to help it mature. Many in the organisation have embraced Digital only to find themselves held back by outdated thinking and processes elsewhere, which stifle innovation & sales. 

Fresh blood is good (and necessary, given the long average FJ tenure) but getting it from similarly monolithic competitors won't help. 

Reduce the amount of monitoring/tracking/governance to enable agility and competition with other large SI's and smaller players. This will also improve the bottom line.

Look at breaking out some truly standalone businesses that don't have all the corporate legacy/governance but give them enough funding and time to deliver. It is well proven that large corporates cannot incubate disruptive technologies within their normal walls. Their legacy crushes it. Fujitsu is suffering from this.

review_title: Red tape all over the place
pros:
Salary is above the average.
Good work/life balance.
cons:
Red tape all over the place. 
They want you to be honest, they value sincerity. When the time comes for you to say what you think, to provide feedback, you are judged based on your opinion. Be prepared to hear a lot of, "talk to your manager", "you can approach HR", etc. When you provide your feedback you will be put aside and viewed as a blocker/problem maker.
Thanks to this, people talk a lot among themselves about what they think but never reach out to their managers, or any hierarchy about what they think.

Internal progression based more on your ability to sell yourself, rather than performance, ability to execute, evidences. Problem is, people sell themselves and no questions asked.
Perception is king!

No bonus pay for any role above Agent.

Company grew a lot in the recent years, support structures failed to keep up with it.

Very hard to park in the area, unless you come in to work real early in the morning.
Advice to Management
LISTEN (plain simple listening to what is being said and not what you interpret of what is being said) and ACT upon it.

Forget the anonymous surveys every year and all the actions and meetings to try to tackle the results from it... The above should clear out those issues. Once and for all.

review_title: Was good at first, not anymore...
cons:
ltant in Bracknell, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Joined the company over 2 years ago, was a conscious decision to move back into full time employment with the stability that offered, by joining a large multinational company, incl good pension, company car and other benefits i.e health care cash plan. Potential for ongoing training and career improvement. Also a very good work / life balance.
Cons
Since then the company has undertaken a massive cost cutting exercise as part of it's 20/20 vision, this has led to a wide range of job cuts across the UK, incl. outsourcing to offshoring facilities in India. This has has led to a total drop in morale, at least for myself and colleagues / peers in the UK who are currently in a redundancy exercise and not sure if we will keep our jobs or not. But still expected to put in the extra effort to meet client commitments. Makes you question the company's ethics of the 'Fujitsu way' and responsible business. No trust or belief in the leadership team, they don't appear to understand the challenges faced by staff on the ground dealing with clients.
Advice to Management
Be more honest to employees, treat them with respect. Re-establish an employee forum / charter (Fujitsu Voice) - which the company served notice on last year which resulted in their termination in January '17.

review_title: New Business Sales - Avoid unless you are taking on a house account.
pros: Good Work-Life balance, flexible working and a decent overall compensation package. Baker Street sales office is a good place to be based in London. Good if you are on a long-standing house account, especially in Public Sector.
cons:
They have left it far too late to change to align to the new market requirements of cloud, mobility and digital transformation and as a consequence are now way behind the likes of Accenture, Capgemini and IBM who all transformed several years ago.
Not enough offshoring and automation of back-end delivery and are losing deal after deal on price against competitors who do. Too many senior managers from old-world backgrounds (BT, HP) and no-one in a U.K. Leadership role with any experience of transforming a business into one fit for the digital world.
Next 2 years are going to be unpleasant as they shed 1/3 of their UK workforce and political agendas, protectionism and navel-gazing dominate.
Advice to Management
Think about the opportunity to use the next 2 years of change to be bold and leapfrog the competition, rather than just play catchup where the competition will have moved on again by the time the program is completed. Sadly, I got the impression that this won't be the case - hence my leaving to join a growing business rather than stay at one clearly in decline.

review_title: Risk of redundancy today, perhaps new opportunities in the pipeline
pros: Large international company, wide spectrum of roles with some flexibility to move around if you network and drive it. Some good managers (I have had mixed experiences). Offices all over the UK and internationally. Some roles and mangers support flexible working, some don't. Fair company pension contribution, healthcare, 25 +/- 5 days leave, company car for most management roles, and other benefits. The majority of people I have worked with have been perfectly pleasant. Many employees stay with Fujitsu long term, and many return after leaving because it is generally 'comfortable', though less so today with redundancies.
cons:
Significant restructuring and redundancies; leadership is very selective about what information is released. Some line managers are not good. Work-life balance in some roles can be poor if you want to do a good job. Long term employees will fall far behind market rate. No company share or investment benefits (Japanese company). Appraisal process is a formality, which fails to recognise or reward individual performances. Feeling less like the people company of 10 years ago and culture starting to align more closely with our American competitors.

12 months ago I would have recommended Fujitsu, today I would suggest waiting for the restructuring to complete.
Advice to Management
Share the more detailed information you are withholding about the restructuring. Share the target company structure, not just the cuts you want to make, as today we feel like numbers on a P&L. Provide more information on the skills required and how you intend to secure or develop them. Use the appraisal process to drive and reward good performance; it does neither.
